It's deceptive to talk about females' "preference" for the underdog, as if it were a conscious choice. All that's happening is that, if blue is more scarce then yellows will tend to dominate because they beat or tie most of the competition. Once that happens, then any individual blue will have a strong mating advantage, because the population is dominated by the one they beat, which helps them mate more and get back in equilibrium. So any given individual that's a member of a color that's in the minority would have an easier time getting a female, because the one they beat in the mating game is dominant in the population, and the one that beats them is suffering in the population. This is not due to conscious choice on the part of the female.

This is some of the most fascinatingly simple behaviors I've ever seen. When I realized what is going on in this single species is precipitated up and down the entire food chain, across most species, I started thinking about nature a lot differently. Now I see this game being played out all over, for example fish and osprey, fish and aquatic insects, aquatic insects and microorganisms, microorganisms and algae. Changing conditions create the detriment of one, which becomes the benefit of another and balance is buffered around a changing environment. Funny how it took a silly game to understand this concept. Kudos Deep Look for taking big ideas and making them digestible.

This is pretty fascinating!
I heard that there is a bird that's similar to this, but employs a very different and more cooperative strategy.
The bird is known as the ruff bird, and male ruff birds have three different morphs:
The Territorial male: The first of the two primary males in the trio and the most common, making up 84% of the males.Territorial males are the biggest, toughest birds of the bunch. They stake out a patch where they do most of their courting and act aggressively towards rival males. He's the ruff bird's equivalent to the Orange Throats.
The Satellite male: The second of the two primary males, making up 16% of males in the group. Smaller and more submissive than the Territorial male, he's pretty similar to the Yellow Throats in that he mostly hangs around the Territorial males and sneakily mates with the females that the Territorial males stock up on.
Now naturally, this causes some conflict between the two males. But there's a third variety who (I guess) acts as a loose parallel to the Blue Throats and keeps the harmony between them: The Faeder male.
The Faeder male is a permanent female mimic, having the dull, bland plumage of the female instead of the flamboyant plumage of the males and is much smaller than his two counterparts. He's also rarer, making up 1% of the males in the trio. The interesting thing about the Faeder male is that he'll often allow the other two males to mate with him as well. This was originally thought to be a mistake on the other males' parts...until it was shown that they too will let him mate with them, showing that they're well aware of the fact that he's a male bird. And he will also mate with the females that they attract sometimes, and indeed, the female ruff birds seem to prefer him to the other two males.
Now how does this keep the harmony between them? Well, hilariously enough, the homosexual activity between the three varieties of male ruff birds actually attracts more females to the males! That's right, the female ruff birds are basically a species-wide example of yaoi fangirls! The more same-sex mating the males engage in, the more females find them attractive. So this way all three male varieties can find plenty of females to mate with and conflicts are kept to a minimum because they're all...(ahem), "working" together to get some!

So...are these all "subspecies"? They're all one species, and yet natural selection has caused all three colour variants to survive, due to the fact that none of them are superior or necessarily preferred in mating. So what would that make each colour? A caste? A subspecies? An entirely different scientific classification all together?

That's correct. The thing is that the Theory of Evolution does not predict altruistic behavior at all. In fact, it predicts the opposite of it, which makes that yet another direct observation that is contrary to TOE predictions -i.e. the TOE cannot account it.

You know, when a theory is so flexible that it claims to explain why organisms change from one kind to another given millions of years while at the same time claiming to explain why they don't change at all within the same time frame (as noted in the video), we have a theory that does not really explain anything at all.

Okay ppl need to learn the difference between evolving and adapting. Evolving is when a species changes into another species. In this case for example from lizard to a mammal if it did evolve. Or from lizard to amphibious. Adapting is when a species adapt to its surrounding or develop ways to survive the cruel cycle of the food change or its daily life style, weather if it is their hunting or mating habits. Also developing unique strategies weather changing appearance or developing unique physical attributes or color is also known as adapting not evolution. I think Blue's strategy is mischaracterized.  Their specialty is cooperation, not monogamy.  So this is really a game of strength v. subterfuge v. teamwork. Blue's behavior says something about human's preference for monogamy as well.

Maybe the females choose the rarest color because they know instinctually that if they have children that match that color they will have a better shot in the gene pool.

If, for example, there are fewer yellow lizards, then the orange and blue lizards won't be on guard for them as much meaning it is easier for the yellow lizards to sneak by.

If there are fewer orange lizards, then they can attract females by seeming so much stronger than all the other lizards because females don't normally see male lizards that big.

And if there are fewer blue lizards, then it is easy for the remaining blue lizards to seem like perfect gentlemen because the orange and yellow lizards behave so much worse toward the females.

So the colors will eventually even themselves out again. But while there is a lesser number of one color, it is to the female's advantage to have children with that color because then their male children will have the advantages listed above, thus increasing the number of their descendants.

What I find interesting is that the behavior and color are so tied together.
Like, in a running set of rock paper scissors, a strategy is to anticipate what your opponent is thinking.
So if you play rock twice, the next round they may think you'll play rock, so will be more likely to play paper, so you should play scissors.
(But that's only if you're one step ahead of the anticipation curve.)

Because if it's just the color that matters to the female, then in such a locked cycle, it may be genetically beneficial for an individual family line to have one color, and ACT like the the color that can beat it.

Or maybe maintaining the three breeds maintains JUST enough diversity as to be beneficial.
